docs.lead_paragraph: What do close friends talk about? Big issues like religion and family, love and health, but filtered through details of daily life. Alicia Suskin Ostriker, an English professor at Rutgers University who lives in Princeton, sees her poetry as a means to ''to fill the center'' those details surround, to strip away the censorship. Her latest collection, ''The Little Space: Poems Selected and New, 1968-1998'' (University of Pittsburgh Press, $16.95 in paperback), her ninth poetry collection, was a National Book Award finalist this year. Many of the experiences and emotions in it are told from a woman's perspective: events like pregnancy and childbirth, marriage and motherhood, aging and illness. Some perspectives are Jewish (one poem is titled ''Holocaust,'' another ''Diaspora''). Some are both. All are written so that readers who have been in these places feel a kinship with her and those who haven't can understand. Friends talk about the weather, too. A new poem, ''April One,'' begins: Can't believe it A million New Jersey hearts whispering rain rain go away.
